coredata.dc:title: Exafs and X-ray diffraction studies of the hydration structure of stereochemically active Sn(II) ions in aqueous solution
coredata.dc:creator: Yamaguchi, T.
Lindqvist, O.
Claeson, T.
Boyce, J.B.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Extended X-ray absorption fine structure measurements have been made on a 3 M Sn(ClO4)2 aqueous solution and on crystalline SnO. Analyses of this EXAFS data reveal the hydration structure of Sn(II) ions and confirm that the Sn(II) lone pairs are strerochemically active in aqueous solution. The results are compared with those obtained by an X-ray diffraction study.

Introduction The HOMO electrons ofSn(tf), corresponding to 5s in the ground stale or the free ion, are usually dis- torted to form a non-spherical charge distribution around this element in sohds (they are "stereochemi- cally active") Structural studies of many Sn(Il) com- pounds have revealed the key role of the active Sn(Il) lone pairs in complex crystal structures [1]. The Sn(ll) lone pairs are also thought to be active in solu- tion. To our knowledge, however, few structural in- vestigations have been performed on the correspond- ing Sn(Il) complex ions in solution. A previous X-ray diffraction study of a concentrated Sn(C104)i aque- oussolution [2] met withsome difficulties in elucida- ting (lie complete hydra lion structure of Sn(II) ions since peaks due to the hydrated Sn^'4' ions, anions and Wilier structures overlapped in the radial distribu- tion curve Recently, the EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure) technique has been devel- oped as a tool for determining the local structure of a particular X-ray absorbing atom in the absence of solvent strucutre [3,4]. In the present study, we de- scribe EXAFS measurements on (he Sn K edge of a 3 M Sn(C10^)7 aqueous solution to determine the hy- dration structure of the Sn(K) ions in aqueous solu- tion. Crystalline SnO was used as a structural stan- dard In addition, the abovementioned X-ray scatter- ing data were re-analysed in the light of the results derived from the present EXAFS study. 2. Experimental The solution of tm(II) perchlorate was prepared under a N, atmosphere by the reaction ofacopper(ll) perchlorate solution with tin metal and acidified slightly with perchloric acid to prevent hydrolysis. Crystalline black SnO was of reagent grade. The solution sample was contained in a Kapton sample cell, while fine powder of the crystalline SnO sample was mixed with epoxy that cured into a sample of the desired thickness. 528 0 009-2614/82/0000-OOOO/S 02.75 1982 North-Holland Volume 93, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24/31 Di.u.-inb.T 1982 EXAFS measurements were performed at the Standard Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (Wiggler line). The X-ray absorption was measured in the vicin- ity of the Sn K edge (29.1 keY). The transmitted radi- ation intensities were registered at 356 photon ener- gies from 28.2 to 30.9 keV with gas loncation detec- tors. The sohd sample was measured at hquid-nitrogen temperature (77 K.)and the solution sample at room temperature. (298 K). Experimental details are de- cnbed elsewhere [5]. 3. Analysis of EXAFS data and results A standard analysis was used to subtract the slow- ly varying absorption background, convert the EXAFS to A-space, and Fourier transform to r-space [4,5]. The resulting EXAFS data, \(k), multiplied by the wave vector, k, are plotted versus k in fig. 1 for tlie solution sample. Fig. 2 shows the corresponding Fourier transforms,^), for the crystalline SnOand the solution sample. According to the reported struc- ture of SnO at 77 K [6], there are four equidistant Sn-0 bonds (2 224 A) in the first-neighbor shell of the Sn atom. In the more distant shells up to 4 A, there are twelve Sn atoms, four being at 3.54, 3.69 and 3.80 A. In tlie Fourier transform of the crystal- line SnO (fig. 2a), the first peak near 1.75 A can be assigned to four Sn 0 bonds. The difference between the location offhe peak and the known near-neighbor spacing k due to the phase shift The more distant peaks are due to the more distant neighbors for which interference effects are severe due to their close spac- ing [7 j. k(A-'l Fig 1. The EXAFS oscillation 4-x(A) on the Sn K edge in Ihc 3 M Sn(C104)^ aqueous solution as a function of pholoelec- tron momentum k. rig 2 Ke.il pans (solid line) .inil llie nugnituiltfi of [he Fourier tr.inslbrnis of tin: tXAl S on tlie Sn K eilgc in (.1) crystalline SnO at 77 K .mil <b) tlie 3 M Sn(Ci04>2 aqueous soluiion ai 298 K The window used for tlie transform is k =33-11 8 A"'. gaussian broadened by 0 5 A~1 The geometries of oxygen-coordinated Sn(ll) ions varies from a regular trigonal pyramid with three short Sn-0 bonds to a regular square pyramid with four Sn-0 bonds (2.05-2.35 A), with many inter- mediates between these two types (8|. In addition, there are some weak Sn-0 interactions (2.70-3.2 A) on the active lone-pairs side, which complete a dis- torted octahedron around the Sn(II) ion. It has often been discussed whether secondary weak interactions may be regarded as chemical bonds or occur due to crystal packing in compounds. This question may be answered in the present study since no effect of the crystal packing is expected in solution. In order to analyse the EXAFS spectrum in a quantitative manner, we applied a least-squares fitting procedure to the peak in r-space using tlie spectrum of the crystalline SnO as a standard. The radial dis- tance, r, the change in root-mean-square deviation, Ac, relative to the 5n-0 standard at 77 K, and the number of near neighbors, JV, are allowed 10 vary in the refinement procedure as described in detail else- where [5]. Based on the above consideration, we tested two kinds of models for the prominent peak" (A) one type of Sn-OH; bond without any weak secondary bonds and (B)two different types of Sn- OH'? interactions. The refinements were carried out in different r-space regions in order to clieck the con- 529 Volume 93, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24^31 Dccenibci 1982 Table 1 Suucluial paramttiets obiainwl dom a least-squares ("n to the EXArSon Ihe Sn K edge in the region of the first peak fbt 3 M Sn(C104>; solution. Tile comparison range WJS 1.35-2 35 A Model A Mod>;( B Sn-OH^ Sn-OHa r(A) &o(A)iV' <A> au(A w 2 0 3 21 10 8 227 0.13 3 1221 005 1 l R value (";<) 1-5 07 tnbution from the background and from possible more distant neighbors. Final parameter values are given in table 1. The average Sn-GHi distances are 2.21 A (model A) and 3 25 A (model" B). The number of nearest-neighbor water molecules, N, in both cases is close to four. These results agree with a general view of the stereochemically active Sn(ll) ion [1,8]. As seen in fig. 3, both models gave almost the same near-neighbor pair distribution functions, p(r). Thus, the secondary Sn-H^O interactions were not detected in the present EXAFS experiment. This may be inter- preted in such a way that there is no such weak inter- action or, if any, the corresponding p(r) is too broad to contribute 10 the EXAFS. We can say that the in- teraction between the active Sn(II) lone pairs and water molecules is not significant in the solution. i'lg 3. Ne.ir-lu'lghbor Sn-0 pair dislnbution functions for model A ( ) and model B (- - -) 4. Analysis of X-ray scattering data and the results Details of the X-ray scattering measurements and data reduction are contained In ref. [2]. Figs. 4a and 4b show the reduced intensities, i(k), multiplied by k (in this case, * = 4w sin 9/X, B the Bragg angle and \ the wavelength), and the differential form, D(r) - 4l^ 2pQ. of the radial distribution function for the 33 M Sn(a04); aqueous solution. In fig. 4b (dots), the First peak at 1.45 A is due to the Cl-0 bonds in the perchlorate group. The 2.3 A peak is ascribed to the Sn-Orh bonds within hydrated Sn2* ions. The 0 0 interactions In the tetrahedral ClO^ group con- tribute in part to the peak. As to the peak at 2.80 A, previous authors have stated that the weak Sn-H' 0 interactions gave a predominant contribution as in crystals. As mentioned in section 3, however, the EXAFS analysis has shown that such interactions are of minor importance in the solution. Other contribu- tions come from the interaction between the 0 atoms h(A" 10 15 < S ~s- ^ "S o 0-6 '(A) Fig, 4 (a) The icducsd inicnsiuss, i(ft), multiplied by k for the 3.3 M Sn(Cl04); aqueous solution Experimental (dots) and theoroncal ( .model A; - - -, model B). (b) The corresponding iW^s^fln functions. Experimental (dols) and theoretical ( , model A, -, model B). 530 Volume 93, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24/31 Dctcmbcr 1982 in the perchlorate group and anionic hydration water molecules, and from interactions between the water molecules in the first and second hydration shells around the Sn2'*" ion. The broad around 3.6-4.8 A is due mainly to the interactions between Sn2"1" ions and water molecules in the second hydration shell. The C1 H->0 interactions due to the anionic hydration also give rise to a contribution to the peak. In order to obtain the structural parameters of the water coordination around the Sn^* ions, we per- formed quantitative analyses using a least-squares method applied to the reduced intensities. The details of the procedure and the program are described else- where [9.10]. From the features in the distribution curve described above, we used the following struc- tural models for the solution. (1) For the perchlorate ion, a tetrahedral geometry was assumed and only the 0-0 distance, r^_Q, was refined. The root-mean-square deviations, Oci-o an^ Op _o, were fixed to the values calculated from spec- troseopic data [11] (2) The structure of the hydrated Sn24" ion up to the first hydration shell was described by three in- dependent parameters, the distance, /'sn-OHi(l)' root-mean-square deviation, ogn-OHid). and the number of nearest-neighbor water molecules, ^Sn-OHid)- The contribution from the weak Sn-H.,0 interactions was checked by introducing pa- rameters rsn-H^O(r), Sn-H,0(r), a"dA^n_n,0(r) (N = 3 was assumed as in crystals) into the refinements. (3) The interactions between the Sn2* ion and water molecules in the second hydration shell were taken into account using three independent param- eters, rsn-H;iO(ll)>oSn-H20(u)<"id/Vsn-H20dI)- (4) The Cl-H^O interactions arising from the anionic hydration were included and their distance, root-mean-square deviation and the number of inter- actions were allowed to vary. (5) The H^OO-H^OQl) interactions belonging to the two hydration sIieUs of the Sn2* ion were de- scribed by three independent parameters, ''HiOO-HaOdD. HiO(I)-H20(ll)i ^d ^HzCXD-HaOdD- The 0(00^ V-HiO interactions due to the aniome hydration were incorporated in the abova interactions. (6) Beyond the abovementioned discrete structures, a continuum distribution of electrons was introduced for each species, which was described by the usual pa- rameters fn and vin. The resulting parameter values are listed in table 2. Theoretical values from the best fit are com- pared with the experimental ones in fig. 4a and 4b. The agreement between the two values is satisfactory. The short Sn-HiO bond distance obtained is 3.34 A, consistent within the expeirimentat errors with the value obtained from the EXAFS. The number of water molecules bonded to the Sn2* ion is three to four, also in good agreement with the EXAFS result. Previous authors concluded two to three Sn-HiO bonds. Our results, however, are consistent with a general trend of oxygen-coordinated Sn(ll) ions [8). As can be seen in fig. 4. the results of the iwo models are not significantly different. This is because in model B the lack of the weak Sn-H^OO') interactions is compensated with smaller o and larger JV values for 5J| Vuliiine 93 number 6 CHI-M1CAL PHYSICS LETTERS 24/31 Dcicinber 1982 the H;,0(1)-H;,0(11) interactions Thus, the X-ray diffraction study alone could not give clear informa- tion on the weak Sn-H)0 interaction. the NSF through the Division of Materials Research and the NIH through the Biotechnology Resources Program in the Division fo Research Resources (in cooperation with the Department of Energy) 5. Conclusion A combination of EXAPS and X-ray diffraction studies has tevealed the complete liydration structure of the Sn(II) ions in aqueous solution. Three to four water molecules are strongly bonded to the Sn(ll) ion at a distance of 2.25-2 34 A. The Sn(ll) lone pairs are sicreociieiincally active and tlic interaction with water molecules is not significant in aqueous solution. head.ce:title: Exafs and X-ray diffraction studies of the hydration structure of stereochemically active Sn(II) ions in aqueous solution

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Extended X-ray absorption fine structure measurements have been made on a 3 M Sn(ClO4)2 aqueous solution and on crystalline SnO. Analyses of this EXAFS data reveal the hydration structure of Sn(II) ions and confirm that the Sn(II) lone pairs are strerochemically active in aqueous solution. The results are compared with those obtained by an X-ray diffraction study.
